The figure shows two point charges <math alttext="positive uppercase Q" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo><mi>Q</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="negative lowercase q" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>−</mo><mi>q</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> where <math alttext="absolute value of positive uppercase Q is greater than absolute value of negative lowercase q" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>|</mo><mo>+</mo><mi>Q</mi><mo>|</mo></mrow><mo>></mo><mrow><mo>|</mo><mo>−</mo><mi>q</mi><mo>|</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. The charges are at equal distances <math alttext=" D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> to the left and right of the origin, <math alttext="x equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. The horizontal line on which the charges lie is divided into four segments, where segment J consists of any point on the line to the left of <math alttext="x equals negative D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, segment K is any point on the line between <math alttext="x equals negative D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="x equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, segment L is any point between <math alttext="x equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="x equals positive D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>+</mo><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and segment M represents any point on the line to the right of <math alttext="x equals positive D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>+</mo><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) What is the direction of the electric field at the origin? Justify your answer.
(b) What is the sign of the electric potential at the origin? Justify your answer.

(c) In which segment is there at least one point where the electric field is zero? If there is more than one segment, name all segments. If there are no segments, explicitly state this. Justify your answer.

(d) In which segment is there at least one point where the electric potential is zero? If there is more than one segment, name all segments. If there are no segments, explicitly state this. Justify your answer.

The charges are now moved to one-tenth of their original distance from <math alttext="x equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. A Gaussian surface in the form of a cylinder is imagined so that the Gaussian cylinder is coaxial with the line and encloses only segments K and L. (e) Suppose that you are given two small spheres carrying identical, opposite charges <math alttext="positive lowercase q sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mi>q</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="negative lowercase q sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>−</mo><msub><mrow><mi>q</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> where <math alttext="absolute value of positive and negative lowercase q sub 0 is less than than absolute value of negative lowercase q" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>|</mo><mo>±</mo><msub><mrow><mi>q</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub><mo>|</mo></mrow><mo><</mo><mrow><mo>|</mo><mo>−</mo><mi>q</mi><mo>|</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. In which of the four regions could each charge be placed so that the magnitude of the net electric flux through the cylinder increases and the magnitude of the electric field at the origin increases?

The charges <math alttext="positive uppercase Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo><mi>Q</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="negative lowercase q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>−</mo><mi>q</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> are removed and two new point charges are placed on the line. Charge <math alttext="lowercase q sub A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>q</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is placed at <math alttext="x equals negative D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and charge <math alttext="lowercase q sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>q</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is placed at <math alttext="x equals positive D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>+</mo><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. A student, knowing the signs and magnitudes of the charges and the value of <math alttext="D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, correctly writes the equation for the electric field for the segment <math alttext="negative D is less than x, which is less than positive D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>−</mo><mi>D</mi><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mo>+</mo><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> as a function of <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> as <math alttext="E of x is equal to the fraction with numerator, 8 times, open parenthesis, x minus 5, close parenthesis, times, open parenthesis, x minus 20, close parenthesis, and denominator, open parenthesis, x squared minus 100, close parenthesis, squared, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>E</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>8</mn><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>20</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>100</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>E</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is in units of <math alttext="newtons divided by coulombs" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>N</mtext><mo>/</mo><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is in meters, and the positive electric field is directed to the right.(f) What is the value of <math alttext="D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>? Explain how you arrived at your answer.

(g) Suppose that a proton is released from rest just to the right of <math alttext="x equals negative D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, causing it to accelerate to the right.How can the student use the above equation to determine the location where the proton achieves its greatest speed as it moves to the right? It is not necessary to find this location. Explain your reasoning.
